In the future, Alfred hopes to expand his business by selling clothes to various towns in the region.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en: In addition to her charcoal-selling business, Chizi has been able to open a tailoring business. She is so grateful for the support she is getting from Yehu and Kiva. Chizi narrates that since the previous loan, her monthly income has very much increased. Her dream is to open a tailoring and dressmaking training unit. She is requesting this loan that will be used to buy a new sewing machine.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Ummi

texts.en:
Ummi, 26, lives with her life companion and two children in her own house. She sells sells juice and charcoal from her home. She is a visionary woman who wants to get ahead. She also sells ladies' shoes. She’s been in business for four years and has gained much sales experience that allows her to earn the best profits. She has acquired a large clientele that prefers her because of the quality, good prices, and above all excellent service. The loan she is asking will enable her buy a freezer and sacks of charcoal.

Ummi is an enterprising woman who is dedicated to her work and who very much wants to get ahead. She has good payment references and is very responsible. She assures that she’ll be able to repay the loan while at the same time has faith that she’ll provide economic security for her home.

loans.use: buy a freezer and sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with six children and all her children go to school. She takes care of no additional family members. She operates a retail shop from a market. She sells her products on retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 13 years. She works six days a week.

She has requested for a loan of Uganda shillings 300,000 from MCDT – SACCO to buy cooking oil, flour, rice, crates of soda, and other soft drinks. Her major business challenges are ever-increasing prices of commodities and seasonality.

Her goals and aspirations are to expand her business into a wholesale shop and also to educate her children up to university level. She lives in her own house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy more cooking oil, flour, rice, crates of soda, and other soft drinks.

loans.name: Goreth

texts.en:
Gorreth is lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children and two of her children go to school. She has no additional family members. She operates a food stall at the market. She sells her products on a retail basis. She has been in business for the last 7 years. She works seven days a week. She gets additional income from operating a saloon.

She has requested for a loan of 200,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT – SACCO to buy passionfruit, tomatoes, green bananas, cassava, and sweet potatoes. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to increase her capital basis and become a wholesaler and also to educate her children up to university level. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises.

loans.use: to buy more passionfruit, green bananas, and tomatoes.

loans.name: Specioza

texts.en:
Specioza lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with two children and both her children go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells charcoal at the market. She sells her products on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 5 years. She works seven days a week. She has requested for a loan of 200,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT – SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal.

Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goal and aspiration is to buy a plot of land and build a house. She lives in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 18000 through NWTF to purchase more grocery items like soap, sugar and snack foods for her general store business.

Fe has been in this business for eight years. Fe earns additional income from basket weaving.

Fe has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items like soap, sugar and snack foods.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 37 years old, lives in Airport, and stopped her education at 1st grade. She has three children between 2 and 17 years old that are in school and live at home. For the past twenty years she has been selling rice and rubber dishes (cups, bowls, spoons) in the local market. She received money from her husband to start her business. She enjoys her business because it helps to sustain her and her family. She is requesting a loan to purchase bags of rice and rubber dishes for her business. Her plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase bags of rice and rubber dishes for her business.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is 56 years old and a widow with two children.

Francisca works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines. Francisca has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional grocery items like bread, soft drinks, bread and other miscellaneous items.

Francisco has been in this business for 18 years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Francisco aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery items like bread, soft-drinks, bread and other miscellaneous items.

loans.name: Garmai

texts.en: Garmai is 36 years old, lives in Airport, and stopped her education at 4th grade. She is married and has five children between 4 and 19 years old that are in school and live at home. For the past ten years she has been selling rubber dishes (plates, spoons, bowls) in the local market. She requesting a loan to purchase rubber dishes for her business. She started this business on sell-pay (take the goods to sell, return the principles, and have the profit). She sold palm oil at that time. Her plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase rubber dishes for her business.

loans.name: Mamie

texts.en: Mamie is 40 years old, lives in Airport, and she stopped her education in 1st grade. She is married and has 6 children between 1 and 16 years old. Three are in school and live at home. She received money from her husband to start her business. She has been involved in business for 25 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase slippers for her business. Her plan is to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase slippers for her business.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is married with two children and both her children are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. She has a business of selling charcoal and has been in this business for three years selling to all categories of people but on a retail basis only.

She has applied for a loan of 800,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT - SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She works at the market seven days a week.   Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She aspires to become a wholesaler and also to own a fully stocked charcoal store. 

She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Famata

texts.en: Famata is 44 years old and lives in Airport. She is married with three children between 13 and 18 that live at home and attend school. For the past nine years she been selling used clothes in the market. She started this business with money given to her by her husband and learned this way of selling from her mother. She is appreciative of her business because it keeps her saving every day. Her plan is to build a house. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. Her plan is to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Kolu

texts.en: Kolu is 46 years old. She stopped her education in the 9th grade. She is married and lives in Airport with her 6 children between 8 and 24 that are in school. Her husband is a contractor. For ten years now she has been selling palm oil, rice, pepper, etc in the local market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more palm oil, rice, pepper, etc for her business. A problem she faces is that the transportation cost is high. In the future she wants to become a house owner.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil, rice, pepper, etc for her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a rice-farming business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies for her rice-farming business.

Helen has been in this business for eight years. Helen earns additional income from a restaurant.

Helen has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy fertilzers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Anselma

texts.en:
Anselma works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Anselma requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

Anselma has been in this business for six years.

In the future, Anselma would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Gaudencia

texts.en: This time, for her sixth loan cycle, Gaudencia is borrowing 14,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy more fish to sell in her food stall. Her fish vending business that she previously funded through Kiva partner NWTF continues to provide Gaudencia and her family with income that is improving their quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 20,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy more snack foods to sell in her stall.

Amalia has been in this business for 13 years. Amalia earns more income from fish vending.

Amalia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more snack foods to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business making and selling vinegar in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 20,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase more empty gallon containers for her vinegar.

Emma has been in this business for five years. Emma earns more income from fish vending.

Emma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more empty gallon containers for her vinegar.

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en: Florencia is a 56-year-old married woman from Panglao, Bohol. A mother of three children, she has been in the fish vending business for 10 years. She sells fish. She requested a loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos to buy fishing materials like fishnet, gasoline for the motorboat and a container for fish storage. In the future, Florencia would like to expand her business in order to have a sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: to buy fishnet, gasoline for the motorboat and a container for fish storage.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is 49 years old and married with five children.

Analyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (general) store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell such as curls, candies, soft drinks and beverages.

Analyn has borrowed and repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari (general) store for three years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane.

Analyn aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell such as curls, candies, soft drinks and beverages.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is 32 years old and married with two children.

Analyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 29500 loan through NWTF to buy additional products to sell.

Analyn has borrowed and repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for eight years and also earns an income as an Avon dealer.

Analyn aspires to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Yelena

texts.ru:
Елена работает на одном из самых крупных рынков города Мелитополя. Она торгует мужской одеждой, имея свое торговое место. Этим бизнесом занимается уже 17 лет. 
Елена обратилась в КИВА за суммой в 4000 гривен для того, чтобы закупить рубашки и сезонную джинсовую одежду под реализацию осенью-зимой.
texts.en:
Yelena works in one of the biggest markets in the city of Melitopol, where she owns her own stall and sells men's clothing. She has been in this business for 17 years now. 

Yelena turned to KIVA for a loan of 400 griven in order to purchase shirts and seasonal denim clothing for fall and winter.

loans.use: purchase shirts and seasonal denim clothing for fall and winter

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 50 years old, married, with two children who are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Elizabeth has a variety store business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 25000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase grocery items such as bread, soft drinks and other groceries.

Elizabeth has been in this business for 12 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items such as bread, soft drinks and other groceries.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita is 59 years old and married with three children. 

Conchita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 50,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell.

Conchita has borrowed and repaid 22 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 12 years and also earns an income from raising livestock.

Conchita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell in her store.

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia is 41 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. 

She has been raising livestock for three years and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane. Celia works tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

Celia is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy additional livestock to raise.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock to raise.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fruit and vegetable vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of fruit to sell to her customers.

Anita has been in this business for 25 years. Anita earns additional income from selling rice.

Anita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of fruit to sell.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 54 years old and married with five children. She runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from buying and selling charcoal.

Evelyn has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell in her general store. She has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Evelyn works hard to provide for her family, and aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is married and has a herbal medicine business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for three years now.

Jocelyn requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

Jocelyn works hard to support her family. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is 48 years old and married with one child. She runs a general store in the Philippines. Judy has been running the general store for eight years and also earns an income from raising livestock.

Judy works hard to provide for her family. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell in her general store. Before this loan, Judy has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF. 

Judy aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Leonis

texts.en:
Leonis is 47 years old and married with six children. 

She has been running a general store for ten years and also earns an income from buying and selling peanuts and corn.

Leonis has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her store. Leonis has borrowed and repaid 16 loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Leonis works hard to provide for her family, and aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a videoke rental business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for three years. 

Luzminda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She is borrowing PHP 23,000 through NWTF to purchase additional videoke machines for her videoke rental business.

Luzminda earns additional income from a general store, buying and selling rice grains and farming sugarcane.

She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional videoke machines for her videoke rental business.

loans.name: San Antonio Group

texts.es:
San Antonio se formo en la ciudad de Curuguaty, con 14 catorce mujeres, están en su primer ciclo, demostrado unión y solidaridad entre ellas, desean trabajar duro y asi ayudar a sus familias.
Miembro de este grupo es la Sra. Dominga quien vende leche en su barrio, es una persona con grandes sueños y aspiraciones, que se esfuerza por dejar atrás todo lo malo y salir adelante. Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de leche, y así seguir atendiendo a sus clientes.
texts.en:
The San Antonio Group was formed in the city of Curuguaty by 14 women who are in their first loan cycle, demonstrating union and solidarity among themselves.  They want to work hard to help their families.

One of the members of the group is Dominga who sells milk in her neighborhood.  She is someone with great dreams and aspirations, who works hard to leave the bad behind in order to get ahead.  She is requesting a loan to buy milk so she can continue attending to her customers.

loans.use: To buy milk to sell.

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es: María Isabel  de 47 anos de edad madre soltera con un hijo de 26 anos mayor de edad e independiente económicamente. María Isabel es originaria del municipio de  Malpaisillo lugar que esta ubicado en la zona norte del país. Malpaisillo se caracteriza por ser una zona agrícola donde se siembra maíz, plátanos. Ella tiene por actividad económica la venta de cosmético y ropa nueva desde hace 5 anos que se dedica a esta actividad la cual para ella ha sido una forma de vida para poder sostener a su familia. Ella tiene varios anos trabajando con fundación la cual ha demostrado ser responsable en sus pagos en tiempo y forma.  María Isabel esta solicitando el financiamiento para invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio para satisfacer a su clientela y obtener mejores ganancias. Con el financiamiento comprar lápiz labial, delineador, perfumes, crema de cuerpo, astringentes, crema hidrates, sombra de ojos rubor. María Isabel agradece la ayuda que le brindan los inversionistas kiva a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
María Isabel, 47, is a single mother with a 26-year-old adult son who is economically independent.  María Isabel is from the town of Malpaisillo which is located in the northern part of the country.  Malpaisillo is known as an agricultural area where maize and bananas are grown.  She sells cosmetics and new clothing for a living, and has been in business for five years, allowing her to support her family.

For several years she has been working with the Foundation, having shown how responsible she is in paying back the loan on time.  María Isabel is requesting a loan to use as work capital to stock her business to satisfy customers and increase her earnings.  She will use the money to buy lipstick, eyeliner, perfumes, body lotions, soaps, moisturizers, and eye shadow.  María Isabel is grateful for the support Kiva lenders give to people with scarce resources in poor countries such as Nicaragua, so they can earn a decent living.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics such as lipstick, eyeliner, perfumes, body lotions, soaps, moisturizers and eye shadow.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.en:
Leonor is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business renting out boarding houses in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 30 years. 

Leonor also earns an extra income from selling rice.

She is borrowing 18,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy materials to maintain her boarding houses.

Leonor has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF and her dream is to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: buy materials for maintaining her boarding houses.

loans.name: Lutgarda

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Lutgarda works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from poultry and pig raising. 

Lutgarda is borrowing 20,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her restaurant.

Lutgarda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 19 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Medelina

texts.en:
Medelina is 48 years old and married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family, running a general store. She has been running the general store for 14 years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane.

She has requested a 35,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase stock to sell in her store.

Medelina has borrowed and paid back 22 loans from NWTF before this loan. Her dream is to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Elka

texts.es: Doña Elka es una mujer con 37 años de edad, soltera, tiene un hijo menor de edad. Vive sola con su hijo. Es humilde y trabajadora, esforzada por lograr lo que se propone. Su hijo estudia y también le ayuda en los bordados que tiene que hacer a sus trabajos. Es segunda vez que solicita financiamiento a Fundación Mujer.Tiene muchos años de dedicarse a las costuras. Ella confecciona ropa de cama, cortinas, hace costuras a la medida. También tiene una máquina de bordado para sus prendas. En ocasiones le llegan contratos para bordados a uniformes de diferentes instituciones de la zona de Limón. Actualmente genera ingresos también de las ventas de productos amway porque su meta es ahorrar para cumplir su sueño, el cual es comprarse una máquina bordadora industrial.
texts.en:
Elka, 37, is single and lives with her minor child.  She is a humble worker who has made every effort to reach her goals.  Her son goes to school and sometimes helps with the embroidery she does on her sewing work.  This is her second loan through Fundación Mujer.  She has been working as a seamstress for several years and makes bed linens, curtains and made-to-measure items.  She also has an embroidery machine for her clothing.  

Sometimes she receives orders for embroidery on uniforms from different institutions in the Limón area.  Currently, she also earns an income selling Amway products to save toward her goal, which is to buy an industrial embroidery machine.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics for her business.

loans.name: Ramona Antonia

texts.es: Ramona de 40 anos de edad, casada con dos hijos  los cuales están bajo su responsabilidad está estudiando en la Universidad. Es originaria de municipio de León, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona de occidente del país. Ramona se caracteriza por ser unas personas trabajadora, responsable, con ganas de superación personal. Ella tiene por actividad económica la venta de cosméticos ella trabaja por encargo de catálogos con diferentes casa comerciales. El negocio consiste en vender productos como lápiz labial, base, rubor, lápiz de ojos, cremas, perfumes, corrector de ojos, desmaquilladores, sombra de ojos. El negocio lo realiza de forma ambulante y por encargo a clientes fijos y eventuales. Tiene 10 anos de tener el negocio. Negocio que surgió por la necesidad  de tener una fuente de ingresos para el sustento de su familia. Ramona ya ha trabajado con fundación león 2000 y ha demostrado su responsabilidad de pago en  tiempo y forma. El crédito lo necesita para invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio y aprovechar las ofertas de la temporada y espera contar con el apoyo del programa kiva y la fundación león 2000. Ramona agradece la ayuda que le brindan los inversionista kiva a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Ramona, 40, is married and has two children who are in her care and study at the univesity.  She is from the town of León which is in the western part of country.  Ramona is known for being a very hard-working, responsible person who is determined to improve her situation.  She earns a living selling different brands of cosmetics by catalogue.

She sells products such as lipstick, foundation, blush-on, eyeliner, creams, perfumes, eye corrector, make-up remover and eye shadow.  She works on a door-to-door basis and receives orders from fixed and eventual customers.  She has been in business for ten years and started it to have an income to support her family.

Ramona has worked with the León 2000 Foundation before and has proven herself to be responsible in paying back the loan on time.  The loan she needs now is to stock her business and take advantage of the seasonal discounts.  She hopes to receive support through the Kiva Program and the León 2000 Foundation.  Ramona is grateful for the help Kiva lenders give to people with scarce resources in poor countries such as Nicaragua, so they can earn a decent living.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics such as lipstick, foundation, blush-on, eyeliner, creams, perfumes, eye corrector, make-up removers and eye shadow.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
This is Luzviminda, 48, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is a mother and is married to Nelson, a taxi driver.

Together with her husband, Luzviminda manages the household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Luzviminda operates a 'variety' store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five-pesos' worth of cooking oil, or an egg. 

Luzviminda makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue running her business, Luzviminda is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Luzviminda hopes to give her children a quality education and dreams of expanding her business through all her hard work. 

She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for new inventory items for her convenience store.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married and works hard in her general store to support her child.

She has requested a 1,800 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy a solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to give her child bright light during the night.

Regina is aware that by using the solar lamp she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and creating a healthier, safer home for her family.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp.

loans.name: Connie

texts.en:
Connie works hard to support her family. Connie is married and has a fishing/fish vending business in the Philippines.

Connie requested a PHP 24000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fishing equipment.

Connie has been in this business for 20 years now.

In the future, Connie would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing equipment.

loans.name: Rema

texts.en:
Rema works hard to support her family. She is married and has been running a vegetables and spices vending business in the Philippines for seven years now.

Rema has requested a 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase additional produce for her business. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: purchase additional vegetables and spices to sell

loans.name: Angelica

texts.en:
Angelica is a hardworking entrepreneur who runs a sari-sari (general) store in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy items like shampoo and groceries to sell in her store. NWTF is relisting Angelica's business profile in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo and groceries to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Venancia

texts.en:
Venancia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business that buys and sells vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to buy vegetables for her business.

Venancia has been in this business for 10 years. Venancia earns more income from farming vegetables.

Venancia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is 34 years old. She is married and has two children; one of whom is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Jessica has a fishing/fishing vending business in the Philippines. Jessica requested a PHP 17000 loan amount through NWTF to buy materials for fishing boat maintenance.

Jessica has been in this business for 12 years. In the future, Jessica would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials for fishing boat maintenance.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages for her general store

loans.name: Luz Marie

texts.en:
Luz Marie works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business buying and selling fresh coconuts in the Philippines.

Luz Marie has requested a 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more coconuts. She has been running her business for eight years now and in the future, she would like to save money to expand it further.

loans.use: to buy fresh coconuts to sell

loans.name: Nazaria

texts.en:
Nazaria is 56 years old and married with four children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur who has run a restaurant business in the Philippines for 33 years. 

Nazaria has requested a loan of 29,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy additional stock for her restaurant. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock for her restaurant

loans.name: Demerose

texts.en:
Demerose is 42 years old and married with four children. With two children in school, Demerose works very hard to provide for them.

Demerose runs a direct selling business for Avon products in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell. She has been in this business for six years and sells a variety of items such as lotion, perfumes, shirts, etc. 

In the future, Demerose would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional Avon products to sell

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn is 33 years old and married with three children.

Roselyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell in her general store. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Roselyn has borrowed and repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to save enough money that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell in her general store

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is married and has four children. She is 31 years old and lives in Capucao, Ozamis City. 

Sarah cultivates fruits, particularly mangoes and coconuts, for a living. She has been in this work for 12 years and earns PHP 4,000 a month. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 from GDMPC to purchase seeds and seedlings to plant. Sarah been a member of GDMPC since 2011. In the future, Sarah hopes to expand and improve her business to gain more income for her household.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and seedlings to plant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy animal feed for her pigs

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia is 47 years old, married, and has three children. 

Nelia is in the business of raising pigs in the Philippines. Nelia requested a PHP 30000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Nelia has been raising pigs for five years. She has borrowed 30000 PHP in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Nelia would like to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Tisha

texts.en:
During a difficult bout with adult acne, Skinfolk owner, Tisha searched and tried anything that could possibly cure her skin. One day, she placed an order for African black soup and raw shea butter and her body immediately responded to the natural ingredients found in these products. This discovery led Tisha to develop a passion for using and promoting all-natural skin products.

When Tisha lost her job in 2008, she took it as an opportunity to follow her passion and started "Skinfolk", selling her own line of all-natural skincare products. Tisha is currently selling her products on Etsy and at local farmers' markets in San Diego, and her business is growing. However, due to a limited credit history and cash flow, Tisha struggled to secure the financing she needs to take her business to the next level from traditional sources.  

Tisha will use her Kiva loan to market her business and invest in higher quality materials. She hopes that with better marketing opportunities and more inventory, she will be able to increase profits and reach her full business potential. She eventually dreams of creating a stable financial situation for her family and would like to become a fair trade certified business in the near future.

Visit Skinfolk online at: www.myskinfolk.com

loans.use: to market her skincare business and invest in higher quality materials.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is 41 years old and married with six children. She works hard to provide for her family. Rowena runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a loan of PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

Rowena has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for nine years and also earns an income from buying and selling dried fish.

Rowena aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita works hard to support her family. Lolita is married and has a restaurant business in the Philippines.

Lolita requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her business.

Lolita has been in this business for eight years.

Lolita  would like to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is 43 years old, married, and has four children.

She earns a living by fattening pigs in the Philippines. Vilma is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Vilma has been fattening pigs for 10 years. She earns additional income from buying and selling nipa (woven palm mats used for house repair and construction).

She works tirelessly to attain her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a cafeteria business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase additional items for her business.

Rowena has been in this business for 40 years. Rowena earns additional income from a general store.

Rowena has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the financial stability of her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional items for her cafeteria business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy ingredients to be used in making snacks.

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en:
This is Ethel, 49, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Danilo and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to provide income for her family's everyday expenses.  

Ethel operates a bridal gown retailing business. What she basically does is buy bridal gown products from her suppliers and resells them for a profit. Her products are bridal gowns and dresses. Her regular customers are people in the local community.  She earns a minimum of 3,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more bridal gowns and dresses to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ethel hopes to grow her business and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more bridal gowns and dresses to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is a 44-year-old woman from Liposong, Ozamiz City. She is married and has seven children. 

To earn a living, Norma operates a general store. She has been in this business for nine years and earns 7,000 PHP per month. In 2007, Norma joined GDMPC. Norma is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from her business to pay her children's tuition fees and for her family's living expenses.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Mary Jane works hard to support her family. She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from jeep transportation.  

Mary Jane is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase additional fish to sell for her fish vending business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF. Mary Jane hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Luis Gonzalo

texts.es:
El señor Luis Gonzalo, comerciante trabajador, ha tenido varios créditos con la institución y los ha pagado muy bien, labora seis días ala semana desde las cinco de la mañana hasta las cinco de la tarde, en su negocio venta de frutas y verduras, en uno de los mercados capitalinos, su actividad inicia muy temprano debido a que el compra sus productos a productores que llegan a vender y de esta manera abastece su negocio, tiene variedad de frutas y verduras.

 Solicita a Ceprodel  un  préstamo   para invertir en capital de trabajo, para la  compra de frutas y verduras. Esto con el propósito de comprar mas productos, ofreciendo variedad a sus clientes y captar mas compradores.  Agradece  a  ceprodel y Kiva, por la oportunidad y la confianza depositada en el, por lo que este crédito lo invertirá en su negocio  de forma que esto le permitira llevar el sustento a su hogar  e ir mejorando su condición de vida.
texts.en:
Luis Gonzalo is a hard-working merchant.  He has had various loans with the institution, and he has repaid them very well.  He works six days a week from five in the morning until five in the afternoon.  His business is selling fruits and vegetables at one of the markets in the capital.  He starts his business activity very early because he buys the products that he comes to sell, and this way he stocks his business and has a variety of fruit and vegetables.

He is requesting a loan from CEPRODEL to invest working capital in the purchase of more products.  He will do this to offer a variety to his customers and to gain more buyers.  He is grateful to CEPRODEL and Kiva for the opportunity and the trust given to him.  He will use this loan to invest in his business, which will allow him to support his household and to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en: Mrs. Oyun is a 57-year-old woman. She lives with her husband and two sons in Ger in the Govi-Altai province of Mongolia. Her husband is retired and stays at home. Her oldest son is a college student and her youngest son is a secondary school student. Mrs. Oyun started a meat retailing business in 2010 at a rental counter of a local market. She has a good debt record with XacBank. She is requesting a 500,000 tugrik loan to pay her son's university tuition. She is a diligent and hardworking woman.

loans.use: to pay her son's university tuition

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is a 36-year-old married woman. She hails from Maribojoc, Bohol and has six children. 

Zenaida has been in the weaving business for almost one year. She sells native baskets. Aside from her weaving business, she also has a furniture business. She sells round tables and chairs made of wood. Zenaida requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase more materials like bamboo sticks, wood for tables and chairs, and varnish (a transparent, hard, protective finish or film primarily used in wood finishing). 

In the future, Zenaida would like to expand her business to support her family, as well as to finance the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy materials for weaving such as bamboo sticks, wood, and varnish.

loans.name: Josie Jo

texts.en:
Josie Jo is 55 years old and a widow with five children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 30,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell in her general store.

Josie Jo has borrowed and repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her general store for four years and also earns income from farming sugarcane. Josie Jo aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy animal feed for the pigs

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita is 52 years old, married and has three children who are in school. Lolita is in an agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Lolita requested a 15,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy additional feed for her business. Lolita has been raising pigs for four years now, and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Lolita would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional feed for her business

loans.name: Semiona

texts.en: Semiona works hard to support her family. She is married and has a bakery business in the Philippines. Semiona requested a 20,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her bakery. She has been in this business for four years now. In the future, Semiona would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her bakery business

loans.name: Irina

texts.ru:
Ирина живет и работает в Мелитополе. Она торгует мужской одеждой на одном из главных рынков города. У Ирины – свое торговое место. Опыт работы в этой сфере  - 14 лет. 
Ирине понадобилась сумма в 4 000 гривен для того, чтобы закупить мужскую одежду, а именно, футболки и белье на продажу. Ирина намерена развивать свой бизнес, продолжая вкладывать финансы и время в свое дело, тем самым получая средства, которые она сможет использовать для улучшения быта семьи.
texts.en: Irina lives and works in Melitopol where she sells menswear at one of the main city markets. She has her own stall there. She has 14 years of experience in this area. Irina needs 4,000 Ukrainian Hryvnia to purchase menswear, specifically t-shirts and underwear, to resell. She is determined to develop her business by continuing to invest her time and money in her work, thereby generating more funds which she can use to improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to buy menswear, specifically t-shirts and underwear, for resale

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling rice in the Philippines. She is borrowing 21,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell to customers. Virginia has been in this business for two years. She earns additional income from a general store and from selling charcoal.

Virginia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Jenaida

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Jenaida works hard to support her family. She has a furniture making business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store and raising pigs. Jenaida is borrowing 25,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to purchase additional materials for her furniture making business.

Jenaida has been sustaining her business activities with her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for her business

loans.name: Alona

texts.en: Alona is married with six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Alona is 34 years old and has five children who are in school. Alona has a barbecue vending business in the Philippines. She requested a 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. Alona has been in this business for five years. In the future, Alona would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Edgelinda

texts.en:
Edgelinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a furniture making business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 2,5000 Philippine pesos through Negro Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) to purchase additional materials for her furniture making business.

Edgelinda has been in this business for 12 years. She earns more income from a general store and from pig fattening.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for her furniture making business

loans.name: Roxene

texts.en:
Roxene is 36 years old. She is married and has one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Roxene has a business selling fruits in the Philippines. Roxene has been in this business for 10 years.

Roxene requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more fruits to sell in her food stall. 

In the future, Roxene would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida works hard to support her family. She is married and has an ambulant vending dried fish business in the Philippines.

Leonida requested a loan of 15000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

Leonida has been in this business for four years now.

In the future, Leonida would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Sanchirhorol

texts.en:
Mrs. Sanchirhorol is a 29-year-old woman and lives with her husband, daughter, younger brother and father, in Ger, in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business. 

In 2006, she graduated from the Science and Technology University of Mongolia. From 2006 to 2008, she worked at a secondary school as a teacher. In 2011, she started her grocery store business. 

Now, she is planning to open a cafe at the local market. She says that her husband will help her operate her cafe. She has a relative who is a chef and is going to be the chef at her cafe. She is asking for 2,000,000 MNT to purchase equipment and to cover other expenses for her new cafe.

loans.use: to purchase equipment and to cover other expenses for her new cafe.

loans.name: Loyda

texts.en:
This is Loyda, She previously accessed an 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her child’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her child’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Loyda hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Silverita

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Silverita works hard to support her family.

She has a dried fish vending business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store.  

Silverita is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy more stock to sell for her dried fish vending business.

Silverita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 20 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business and send her four children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 25 years old and married. She has two children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Josephine runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, canned goods, soft drinks, etc.
 
Josephine requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

In the future Josephine would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia works hard to support her family. Virginia is single and has a general store business in the Philippines. Virginia has been in this business for three years now, and she also earns additional income from clothing sales.

Virginia requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery items to sell like snack foods, laundry soap, etc.

In the future, Virginia would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items to sell like snack foods, laundry soap, etc.

loans.name: Yiret Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Yiret” está conformado por 21 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran; venta de leña, venta de queso, venta de completos y empanadas, taller mecánico, venta de ropa, venta de comida rápida. Servicios entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Villarrica.
Fabiola, integrante del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra de pie en primera fila, ocupando el primer lugar de derecha a izquierda, viste un chaleco de color gris oscuro, botines de color gris, una cartera que lleva cruzada, su cabello es de color castaño oscuro, lo usa suelto y largo.
Ella se dedica al rubro de la confección, desde hace 4 meses. Comenta que trabaja en su casa realizando cojines y lo que su clientela le va solicitando, además realiza tejidos, su horario de trabajo lo distribuye de acuerdo a su disponibilidad.
La mercadería e insumos que va necesitando para sus costuras y confecciones las compra en locales y distribuidoras donde encuentra géneros y lana a bajo costo, por lo tanto conveniente económicamente.
Con el crédito comprará géneros, hilos, lanas, agujas.
Una de las metas de Fabiola es continuar con el negocio, para generar mayores ingresos, así con esto optar a una mejor calidad de vida.
Fabiola vive junto a su marido y sus tres hijos de 13, 10 y 6  años de edad, todos se encuentran estudiando.
Ella se encuentra muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad de la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio. Respecto al grupo del Banco Comunal del cual forma parte, comenta que en éste existe muy buena comunicación. Por otro lado las capacitaciones, le han servido para aprender nuevas estrategias de venta y contabilidad.
Villarrica es una  ciudad al sur de Chile, ubicada en la región de La Araucanía. Es una ciudad pequeña, pero cuenta con todos los servicios básicos y turísticos, siendo uno de los principales centros de servicios del área cordillerana y principal centro turístico de la región, junto con Pucón. Durante los meses de verano se realizan numerosas actividades y eventos culturales, artísticos y deportivos, Además de las innumerables alternativas de Ecoturismo, Turismo Aventura y Etnoturismo
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Yiret”. It is made up of 21 entrepreneurs who work in different areas. Among them are selling firewood, selling cheese, selling meals and empanadas, a mechanic's garage, selling clothes, and selling fast foods, as well as services. They are all from the city of Villarrica.

Fabiola is a member of the communal bank. In the photo she is in the front row first from the right. She is wearing a dark gray vest, gray boots, and carrying a purse. Her hair is dark brown. long and loose.

She has been a seamstress for 4 months. She works from home making cushions and whatever her customers order. She also does weaving. Her daily schedule varies according to availability.She buys the materials she needs for her sewing at locales and distributors where she finds fabrics and wool at a low cost, therefore it is good for her financially. 

With the loan, she will buy fabric, thread, wool and needles. One of Fabiola's goals is to continue with her business to generate more income and have a better quality of life. Fabiola lives with her husband and her three children, 13, 10 and 6. All of them are in school.   

She is very happy and grateful for the opportunity offered by Fondo Esperanza, because it will allow her to invest in her business. In regards to the communal bank she belongs to, she says that there is very good communication there. The trainings have been useful for her to learn new strategies for selling and accounting.

Villarrica is a city in southern Chile, located in the Araucanía region. It is a small city, but has all of the basic services and tourist attractions. It is one of the main cities in the mountain region as well as one of the main tourist attractions along with Pucón. During the summer, there are many activities and cultural, art and sports events. There is also a lot of eco-tourism, adventure tourism and ethno-tourism.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, thread, wool and needles.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en:
Tomas is from Bagakay, Ozamiz City. He is 34 years old and married, and he has one child. 

To make a living, Tomas owns and operates a general store. Tomas has engaged in his business for three years and earns 10,000 PHP a month. 

Tomas joined GDMPC in 2009. He has requested a loan for 25,000 PHP, which he will use to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee. 

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Rebeca is 55 years old and married. She has six children.

Rebeca works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the general store for seven years and also earns an income from raising livestock. 

Rebeca requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.  She has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Rebeca aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 52 years old, married, and has six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Josephine has a fishing/fish vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 17 years.

Josephine requested a PHP 20,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional materials for her fishing business.

In the future, Josephine would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
As a widow and parent of three children, Salvacion works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from raising pigs.  

Salvacion is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her restaurant business.

Salvacion has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her restaurant.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is 39 years old and has five children who are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Gemma has a trisikad transportation business in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 17,000 Philippine pesos through the Negro Women for Tomorrow Foundation to buy additional trisikad.

Gemma has been in this business for four years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional trisikad.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
This time, for her seventh loan cycle, Lydia is borrowing 23,000 Philippine pesos to purchase more grocery products for her general store business. 

The souvenir business that she previously funded through the Negro Women for Tomorrow Foundation, a Kiva partner, continues to provide Lydia and her family with income that is improving their standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items like bread, soft drinks and detergent

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia works hard to support five children. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 6500 loan through NWTF to buy a SOLAR LAMP.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to provide her children with bright light when they study at night.

Alicia is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase a solar lamp

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is 44 years old and married with five children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business buying & selling charcoal in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy charcoal to sell.

Delia has borrowed and repaid 19 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the charcoal business for 9 years and also earns an income from raising poultry and retailing rice.

Delia aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy charcoal to sell

loans.name: Luvinda

texts.en:
Luvinda is 34 years old and married with six children. Five of her children are in school, and Luvinda works very hard to provide for them.

Luvinda runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. She has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap and other groceries. 

In the future, Luvinda would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en:
This is Anatalia, 50, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to John, a driver, and a mother to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Anatalia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Anatallia hopes to give her children a good and high quality education and dreams of expanding her business through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling spices in the Philippines. Gemma has been in this business for 16 years. She earns additional income from selling gasoline.

She is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase additional spices to sell.

Gemma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional spices to sell.

loans.name: Juaquina

texts.es:
Juaquina de 70 años, quien comparte toda su vida a lado de su esposo, Edmundo de 69 años. Juntos han logrado que sus hijos sean hoy personas independientes y de buen proceder. Lograron con años de trabajo concretar su casa de material noble. Desde siempre fue la gestora y apoyo de las actividades de su esposo, quien se dedica en carpintería y ebanistería y que gracias a sus 40 años lograron acumular dinero suficiente que le permitió la construcción del inmueble, asi como sus pisos. Pasado un tiempo lograron ampliar su casa, siendo un espacio dedicado para el alquiler a terceros para uso comercial. Ahora solo viven de las rentas, aluilando habitaciones y dos ambientes para comercio. Según ella, manifiesta que su edad avanzada ya no le permite desempeñar sus labores como antes. Debido a la llegada de profesionales a la zona para desempeñarse laboralmente, la demanda de habitaciones para uso prolongado ha mostrado un crecimiento considerable viendo en ellos una oportunidad económica. Por ello han optado en los últimos meses en acoplar y culminar con los acabados de los ambientes recientemente construidos y destinarlos para el respectivo alquiler.
A futuro tiene planeado techar el último piso de su vivienda para así ampliar la cobertura de cuartos permitiéndole a ella y su esposo defenderse económicamente gracias al rubro. Este es su crédito 18 por el cual es considerada por el grupo en su conjunto como una de las personas más cumplidoras en el pago de su préstamo, Así mismo considera que el trabajo con su banco comunal le ha permitido crecer económicamente con personas de su entorno. Con los 500 nuevos soles complementará el capital que tiene destinado para realizar los acabados del ambiente de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Juaquina is 70 years old. She shares her life with her husband, Edmundo, who is 69. Together, they have been able to raise their children in a good home. Over the years, they were able to build their house out of brick. Juaquina was always a consultant and supporter of her husband's activities. He works in carpintry and furniture making. After 40 years, thery were able to save enough to build their house. After a while, they were able to enlarge it and have a space to rent out to others for commercial use. Now they live on renting out rooms and two commercial spaces. According to Juaquina, her advanced age does not let her work the way she used to.Since people have been coming to the area to work, the demand for rooms for the long term has grown considerably and they see a financial opportunity in it. That is why in the last few months they have decided to build and finish construction on rooms and rent them out. 

In the future they plan on putting a roof on the top floor of their house to cover the rooms. This way, she and her husband can get by financially. This is her 18th loan she has taken out with the group. She is one of the most responsible people in the group when it comes to paying off her loans,She also thinks that the work with her communal bank has allowed her to grow financially with the people around her. With the 500 nuevos soles, she will add to the capital she has set aside for finishing the rooms in her house.

loans.use: to pay to finish construction on her house.

loans.name: Fatima Del Carmen

texts.es: Fátima, una joven de 22 años de edad, originaria de León, madre soltera de tres hijos de 6, 4 y 1 año edad respectivamente, ella se dedica a vender mariscos, desde hace 6 años. Este negocio lo empezó con ayuda de su madre, pues se convirtió en mama a temprana edad, el papa de sus hijos la abandono dejándola sin nada. Solo su madre y hermano le ayudaron a salir adelante pues fueron ellos que le sugirieron que vendiera pescado y es el negocio del cual sobrevive y mantiene a sus tres hijos. Su expectativa  es construir un local donde pueda almacenar mayor cantidad de mariscos para conservar su calidad y frescura. Está solicitando el financiamiento para comprar pescado al por mayor. Esto le ayudara a mejorar sus ventas, atender a más clientela.
texts.en:
Fátima, 22 years old, is originally from León. She is a single mother with three children, ages 1, 4, and 6. She has made a living selling seafood for the past six years. She started her business with the help of her mother, because she became a mother herself very young. The father of her children abandoned her, leaving her with nothing. Only her mother and brother helped her to succeed, as they were the ones who suggested that she start selling fish. 

This business has helped her survive and maintain her three children. Her wish is to construct a storage space where she can keep a larger quantity of seafood, in order to conserve its quality and freshness. She is applying for a loan to buy wholesale fish. This will help her to improve her sales and serve a larger client base.

loans.use: to buy fish.

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda is 43 years old, married and has four children. 

Glenda is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. She has been farming rice for 20 years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Glenda requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

In the future, Glenda would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 41 years old and married. She has four children who are in school, and she works very hard to provide for them.

Jean runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 15 years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, noodles, sugar, soft drinks, etc. 

Jean requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell.

In the future, Jean would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell.

loans.name: Rali

texts.fr: Rali est âgée de 54 ans et est une veuve. Rali est mère de deux enfants dont un ne fréquente pas. Rali n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Rali vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule, les divers besoins de ses enfants ainsi que les siens. Pour contribuer aux différents besoins, Rali exerce depuis une trentaine d’année, la vente des articles et des gluants à son domicile. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses besoins. Rali s’approvisionne dans sa région. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Rali sollicite pour la quatrième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce prêt lui permettra de rehausser le niveau de son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle et son revenu. Les trois premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Rali is a 54-year-old widow and mother of two children, one of whom goes to school. Rali did not go to school herself. She lives with her children and, alone, provides for their needs as well as her own.

To support her family, Rali has been selling sticky types of food and other items for the past thirty years or so. This business has enabled her to provide for her family's needs without much difficulty. Rali stocks up in her region.

Striving to satisfy her customers and grow her sales and revenue, Rali is seeking a loan from ALIDé for the fourth time. The loan will allow her to grow her business, customer base, and revenue. The three previous loans were all correctly repaid.

loans.use: to buy sticky types of food

loans.name: Elba Luz

texts.es: Elba Luz de  38 anos de edad, casada con dos hijos menores de edad de 11 y 5 anos. Ella es originaria del departamento de león, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona de occidente del país. León es un lugar con gente muy acogedora y se caracteriza por ser una ciudad universitaria, donde se encuentra las más antigua y prestigiosa universidad del país. Elba luz tiene por actividad económica la venta de mercadería la cual consiste en vender ropa como pantalones, camisas, short, faldas, camisetas, pijamas, ropa de cama, ropa interior. La actividad la desempeña desde hace 10 anos. La rutina diaria de Elba es trabajar unas 10 horas diaria ofreciendo su mercadería de forma ambulante donde tiene que cargar un bulto de unos 20 kg diariamente para ofrecer su mercadería a clientes  fijos y eventuales. Ella ya ha trabajado con fundación león 2000 y ha demostrado ser responsable en sus pagos en tiempo y forma. El préstamo lo esta solicitando para invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su mercadería y aprovechar la temporada ya que se acercan las fechas festivas como son las promociones y navidad donde la gente compra ropa para estrenarse en esas diferentes ocasiones. Elba Luz agradece la ayuda que le brindan los inversionistas kiva a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en: Elba Luz is 38 years old. She is married and has two children, aged 11 and 5. She is from the department of León, located in the western part of the country. León is a place with kind people and is a university town, with the oldest and most prestigious university in the country. Elba Luz' economic activity is selling merchandise such as pants, shirts, shorts, skirts, t-shirts, pajamas, bedclothes, and underwear. He has done this actiivty for 10 years. Elba's daily routine is to work around 10 hours a day, offering her merchandise door to door. She carries a load of around 20 kg. to offer her merchandise to regular and incidental customers. She has worked with the Fundación León 2000 already and has shown herself to be responsible and punctual in her payments. She is asking for the loan to invest in working capital and stock merchandise to take advantage of the season. The holidays are coming soon and Christmas festivals when people buy clothes to look good on different occasions. Elba Luz is grateful for the help from the Kiva investors for low income people in poor countries such as Nicaragua, so they can have a way to have dignified work.

loans.use: to invest working capital in stocking her business of buying and selling clothes such as pants, shirts, shorts, skirts, pajamas, bedclothes, and underwear.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Elisa works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from her general store.  Elisa is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her restaurant business.

Elisa has been sustaining her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Allah Joy

texts.en:
Allah Joy is 38 years old and single. She works hard to provide for her extended family. She runs a business buying and selling charcoal in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional charcoal to sell.

Allah Joy has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the business buying and selling charcoal for two years and also earns an income from her general store.

Allah Joy aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional charcoal to sell

loans.name: Joan

texts.en: Joan is separated with one child. She is 23 years old and lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Joan has been cultivating coconuts and mangoes for 3 years and earns about 5,200 PHP a month just by doing this type of business. She requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to pay for services to increase crop yield. Joan joined GDMPC in 2011. In the future, she hopes to gain double the income from her business.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Richie

texts.en:
Richie is 26 years old and married with one child. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.
